verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 1:1
verses.text: Book : The Methods of Marcion's Argument Incorrect and Absurd.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 1:2
verses.text: The Proper Course of the Argument.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 1:3
verses.text: The occasion of reproducing this little work, the fortunes of which we noticed in the preface of our first book, has furnished us with the opportunity of distinguishing, in our treatment of the subject of two Gods in opposition to Marcion, each of them with a description and section of his own, according to the division of the subject-matter, defining one of the gods to have no existence at all, and maintaining of the Other that He is rightly God; thus far keeping pace with the heretic of Pontus, who has been pleased to admit one unto, and exclude the other.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 1:4
verses.text: For he could not build up his mendacious scheme without pulling down the system of truth.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 1:5
verses.text: He found it necessary to demolish some other thing, in order to build up the theory which he wished.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 1:6
verses.text: This process, however, is like constructing a house without preparing suitable materials.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 1:7
verses.text: The discussion ought to have been directed to this point alone, that he is no god who supersedes the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 1:8
verses.text: Then, when the false god had been excluded by certain rules which prescriptively settle what is the character of the One only perfect Divinity, there could have remained no longer any question as to the true God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 1:9
verses.text: The proof of His existence would have been clear, and that, too, amid the failure of all evidence in support of any other god; and still clearer would have seemed the point as to the honour in which He ought without controversy to be held: that He ought to be worshipped rather than judged; served reverentially rather than handled critically, or even dreaded for His severity.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 1:10
verses.text: For what was more fully needed by man than a careful estimate of the true God, on whom, so to speak, he had alighted, because there was no other god?.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 2:1
verses.text: The True Doctrine of God the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 2:2
verses.text: The Heretics Pretended to a Knowledge of the Divine Being, Opposed to and Subversive of Revelation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 2:3
verses.text: God's Nature and Ways Past Human Discovery.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 2:4
verses.text: Adam's Heresy.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 2:5
verses.text: We have now, then, cleared our way to the contemplation of the Almighty God, the Lord and Maker of the universe.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 2:6
verses.text: His greatness, as I think, is shown in this, that from the beginning He made Himself known: He never hid Himself, but always shone out brightly, even before the time of Romulus, to say nothing of that of Tiberius; with the exception indeed that the heretics, and they alone, know Him not, although they take such pains about Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 2:7
verses.text: They on this account suppose that another god must be assumed to exist, because they are more able to censure than deny Him whose existence is so evident, deriving all their thoughts about God from the deductions of sense; just as if some blind man, or a man of imperfect vision, chose to assume some other sun of milder and healthier ray, because he sees not that which is the object of sight.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 2:8
verses.text: There is, O man, but one sun which rules this world and even when you think otherwise of him, he is best and useful; and although to you he may seem too fierce and baneful, or else, it may be, too sordid and corrupt, he yet is true to the laws of his own existence.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 2:9
verses.text: Unable as you are to see through those laws, you would be equally impotent to bear the rays of any other sun, were there one, however great and good.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 2:10
verses.text: Now, you whose sight is defective in respect of the inferior god, what is your view of the sublimer One? Really you are too lenient to your weakness; and set not yourself to the proof of things, holding God to be certainly, undoubtedly, and therefore sufficiently known, the very moment you have discovered Him to exist, though you know Him not except on the side where He has willed His proofs to lie.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 2:11
verses.text: But you do not even deny God intelligently, you treat of Him ignorantly; nay, you accuse Him with a semblance of intelligence, whom if you did but know Him, you would never accuse, nay, never treat of.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 2:12
verses.text: You give Him His name indeed, but you deny the essential truth of that name, that is, the greatness which is called God; not acknowledging it to be such as, were it possible for it to have been known to man in every respect, would not be greatness.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 2:13
verses.text: Isaiah even so early, with the clearness of an apostle, foreseeing the thoughts of heretical hearts, asked, "Who hath known the mind of the Lord? For who hath been His counsellor? With whom took He counsel?…or who taught Him knowledge, and showed to Him the way of understanding?" With whom the apostle agreeing exclaims, "Oh the depth of the riches both of the wisdom and knowledge of God! how unsearchable are His judgments, and His ways past finding out!" "His judgments unsearchable," as being those of God the Judge; and "His ways past finding out," as comprising an understanding and knowledge which no man has ever shown to Him, except it may be those critics of the Divine Being, who say, God ought not to have been this, and He ought rather to have been that; as if any one knew what is in God, except the Spirit of God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 2:14
verses.text: Moreover, having the spirit of the world, and "in the wisdom of God by wisdom knowing not God," they seem to themselves to be wiser than God; because, as the wisdom of the world is foolishness with God, so also the wisdom of God is folly in the world's esteem.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 2:15
verses.text: We, however, know that "the foolishness of God is wiser than men, and the weakness of God is stronger than men".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 2:16
verses.text: Accordingly, God is then especially great, when He is small to man; then especially good, when not good in man's judgment; then especially unique, when He seems to man to be two or more.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 2:17
verses.text: Now, if from the very first "the natural man, not receiving the things of the Spirit of God," has deemed God's law to be foolishness, and has therefore neglected to observe it; and as a further consequence, by his not having faith, "even that which he seemeth to have hath been taken from him"—such as the grace of paradise and the friendship of God, by means of which he might have known all things of God, if he had continued in his obedience—what wonder is it, if he, reduced to his material nature, and banished to the toil of tilling the ground, has in his very labour, downcast and earth-gravitating as it was, handed on that earth-derived spirit of the world to his entire race, wholly natural and heretical as it is, and not receiving the things which belong to God? Or who will hesitate to declare the great sin of Adam to have been heresy, when he committed it by the choice of his own will rather than of God's?  Except that Adam never said to his fig-tree, Why hast thou made me thus? He confessed that he was led astray; and he did not conceal the seducer.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 2:18
verses.text: He was a very rude heretic.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 2:19
verses.text: He was disobedient; but yet he did not blaspheme his Creator, nor blame that Author of his being, Whom from the beginning of his life he had found to be so good and excellent, and Whom he had perhaps made his own judge from the very first.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 3:1
verses.text: God Known by His Works.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 3:2
verses.text: His Goodness Shown in His Creative Energy; But Everlasting in Its Nature; Inherent in God, Previous to All Exhibition of It.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 3:3
verses.text: The First Stage of This Goodness Prior to Man.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 3:4
verses.text: It will therefore be right for us, as we enter on the examination of the known God, when the question arises, in what condition He is known to us, to begin with His works, which are prior to man; so that His goodness, being discovered immediately along with Himself, and then constituted and prescriptively settled, may suggest to us some sense whereby we may understand how the subsequent order of things came about.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 3:5
verses.text: The disciples of Marcion, moreover, may possibly be able, while recognising the goodness of our God, to learn how worthy it is likewise of the Divine Being, on those very grounds whereby we have proved it to be unworthy in the case of their god.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 3:6
verses.text: Now this very point, which is a material one in their scheme, Marcion did not find in any other god, but eliminated it for himself out of his own god.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 3:7
verses.text: The first goodness, then, was that of the Creator, whereby God was unwilling to remain hidden for ever; in other words, (unwilling) that there should not be a something by which God should become known.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 3:8
verses.text: For what, indeed, is so good as the knowledge and fruition of God? Now, although it did not transpires that this was good, because as yet there existed nothing to which it could transpire, yet God foreknew what good would eventually transpire, and therefore He set Himself about developing His own perfect goodness, for the accomplishment of the good which was to transpire; not, indeed, a sudden goodness issuing in some accidental boon or in some excited impulse, such as must be dated simply from the moment when it began to operate.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 3:9
verses.text: For if it did itself produce its own beginning when it began to operate, it had not, in fact, a beginning itself when it acted.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 3:10
verses.text: When, however, an initial act had been once done by it, the scheme of temporal seasons began, for distinguishing and noting which, the stars and luminaries of heaven were arranged in their order.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 3:11
verses.text: "Let them be," says God, "for seasons, and for days, and years".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 3:12
verses.text: Previous, then, to this temporal course, (the goodness) which created time had not time; nor before that beginning which the same goodness originated, had it a beginning.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 3:13
verses.text: Being therefore without all order of a beginning, and all mode of time, it will be reckoned to possess an age, measureless in extent and endless in duration; nor will it be possible to regard it as a sudden or adventitious or impulsive emotion, because it has nothing to occasion such an estimate of itself; in other words, no sort of temporal sequence.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 3:14
verses.text: It must therefore be accounted an eternal attribute, inbred in God, and everlasting, and on this account worthy of the Divine Being, putting to shame for ever the benevolence of Marcion's god, subsequent as he is to (I will not say) all beginnings and times, but to the very malignity of the Creator, if indeed malignity could possibly have been found in goodness.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 4:1
verses.text: The Next Stage Occurs in the Creation of Man by the Eternal Word.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 4:2
verses.text: Spiritual as Well as Physical Gifts to Man.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 4:3
verses.text: The Blessings of Man's Free-Will.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 4:4
verses.text: The goodness of God having, therefore, provided man for the pursuit of the knowledge of Himself, added this to its original notification, that it first prepared a habitation for him, the vast fabric (of the world) to begin with, and then afterwards the vaster one (of a higher world,) that he might on a great as well as on a smaller stage practise and advance in his probation, and so be promoted from the good which God had given him, that is, from his high position, to God's best; that is, to some higher abode.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 4:5
verses.text: In this good work God employs a most excellent minister, even His own Word.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 4:6
verses.text: "My heart," He says, "hath emitted my most excellent Word".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 4:7
verses.text: Let Marcion take hence his first lesson on the noble fruit of this truly most excellent tree.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 4:8
verses.text: But, like a most clumsy clown, he has grafted a good branch on a bad stock.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 4:9
verses.text: The sapling, however, of his blasphemy shall be never strong: it shall wither with its planter, and thus shall be manifested the nature of the good tree.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 4:10
verses.text: Look at the total result: how fruitful was the Word! God issued His fiat, and it was done: God also saw that it was good; not as if He were ignorant of the good until He saw it; but because it was good, He therefore saw it, and honoured it, and set His seal upon it; and consummated the goodness of His works by His vouchsafing to them that contemplation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 4:11
verses.text: Thus God blessed what He made good, in order that He might commend Himself to you as whole and perfect, good both in word and act.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 4:12
verses.text: As yet the Word knew no malediction, because He was a stranger to malefaction.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 4:13
verses.text: We shall see what reasons required this also of God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 4:14
verses.text: Meanwhile the world consisted of all things good, plainly foreshowing how much good was preparing for him for whom all this was provided.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 4:15
verses.text: Who indeed was so worthy of dwelling amongst the works of God, as he who was His own image and likeness? That image was wrought out by a goodness even more operative than its wont, with no imperious word, but with friendly hand preceded by an almost affable utterance: "Let us make man in our image, after our likeness".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 4:16
verses.text: Goodness spake the word; Goodness formed man of the dust of the ground into so great a substance of the flesh, built up out of one material with so many qualities; Goodness breathed into him a soul, not dead but living.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 4:17
verses.text: Goodness gave him dominion over all things, which he was to enjoy and rule over, and even give names to.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 4:18
verses.text: In addition to this, Goodness annexed pleasures to man so that, while master of the whole world, he might tarry among higher delights, being translated into paradise, out of the world into the Church.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 4:19
verses.text: The self-same Goodness provided also a help meet for him, that there might be nothing in his lot that was not good.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 4:20
verses.text: For, said He, that the man be alone is not good.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 4:21
verses.text: He knew full well what a blessing to him would be the sex of Mary, and also of the Church.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 4:22
verses.text: The law, however, which you find fault with, and wrest into a subject of contention, was imposed on man by Goodness, aiming at his happiness, that he might cleave to God, and so not show himself an abject creature rather than a free one, nor reduce himself to the level of the other animals, his subjects, which were free from God, and exempt from all tedious subjection; but might, as the sole human being, boast that he alone was worthy of receiving laws from God; and as a rational being, capable of intelligence and knowledge, be restrained within the bounds of rational liberty, subject to Him who had subjected all things unto him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 4:23
verses.text: To secure the observance of this law, Goodness likewise took counsel by help of this sanction: "In the day that thou eatest thereof, thou shalt surely die".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 4:24
verses.text: For it was a most benignant act of His thus to point out the issues of transgression, lest ignorance of the danger should encourage a neglect of obedience.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 4:25
verses.text: Now, since it was given as a reason previous to the imposition of the law, it also amounted to a motive for subsequently observing it, that a penalty was annexed to its transgression; a penalty, indeed, which He who proposed it was still unwilling that it should be incurred.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 4:26
verses.text: Learn then the goodness of our God amidst these things and up to this point; learn it from His excellent works, from His kindly blessings, from His indulgent bounties, from His gracious providences, from His laws and warnings, so good and merciful.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 5:1
verses.text: Marcion's Cavils Considered.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 5:2
verses.text: His Objection Refuted, i-e:, Man's Fall Showed Failure in God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 5:3
verses.text: The Perfection of Man's Being Lay in His Liberty, Which God Purposely Bestowed on Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 5:4
verses.text: The Fall Imputable to Man's Own Choice.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 5:5
verses.text: Now then, ye dogs, whom the apostle puts outside, and who yelp at the God of truth, let us come to your various questions.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 5:6
verses.text: These are the bones of contention, which you are perpetually gnawing! If God is good, and prescient of the future, and able to avert evil, why did He permit man, the very image and likeness of Himself, and, by the origin of his soul, His own substance too, to be deceived by the devil, and fall from obedience of the law into death? For if He had been good, and so unwilling that such a catastrophe should happen, and prescient, so as not to be ignorant of what was to come to pass, and powerful enough to hinder its occurrence, that issue would never have come about, which should be impossible under these three conditions of the divine greatness.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 5:7
verses.text: Since, however, it has occurred, the contrary proposition is most certainly true, that God must be deemed neither good, nor prescient, nor powerful.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 5:8
verses.text: For as no such issue could have happened had God been such as He is reputed—good, and prescient, and mighty—so has this issue actually happened, because He is not such a God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 5:9
verses.text: In reply, we must first vindicate those attributes in the Creator which are called in question—namely, His goodness and foreknowledge, and power.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 5:10
verses.text: But I shall not linger long over this point for Christ's own definition comes to our aid at once.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 5:11
verses.text: From works must proofs be obtained.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 5:12
verses.text: The Creator's works testify at once to His goodness, since they are good, as we have shown, and to His power, since they are mighty, and spring indeed out of nothing.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 5:13
verses.text: And even if they were made out of some (previous) matter, as some will have it, they are even thus out of nothing, because they were not what they are.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 5:14
verses.text: In short, both they are great because they are good; and God is likewise mighty, because all things are His own, whence He is almighty.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 5:15
verses.text: But what shall I say of His prescience, which has for its witnesses as many prophets as it inspired? After all, what title to prescience do we look for in the Author of the universe, since it was by this very attribute that He foreknew all things when He appointed them their places, and appointed them their places when He foreknew them? There is sin itself.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 5:16
verses.text: If He had not foreknown this, He would not have proclaimed a caution against it under the penalty of death.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 5:17
verses.text: Now if there were in God such attributes as must have rendered it both impossible and improper for any evil to have happened to man, and yet evil did occur, let us consider man's condition also—whether it were not, in fact, rather the cause why that came to pass which could not have happened through God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 5:18
verses.text: I find, then, that man was by God constituted free, master of his own will and power; indicating the presence of God's image and likeness in him by nothing so well as by this constitution of his nature.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 5:19
verses.text: For it was not by his face, and by the lineaments of his body, though they were so varied in his human nature, that he expressed his likeness to the form of God; but he showed his stamp in that essence which he derived from God Himself (that is, the spiritual, which answered to the form of God), and in the freedom and power of his will.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 5:20
verses.text: This his state was confirmed even by the very law which God then imposed upon him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 5:21
verses.text: For a law would not be imposed upon one who had it not in his power to render that obedience which is due to law; nor again, would the penalty of death be threatened against sin, if a contempt of the law were impossible to man in the liberty of his will.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 5:22
verses.text: So in the Creator's subsequent laws also you will find, when He sets before man good and evil, life and death, that the entire course of discipline is arranged in precepts by God's calling men from sin, and threatening and exhorting them; and this on no other ground than that man is free, with a will either for obedience or resistance.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 6:1
verses.text: This Liberty Vindicated in Respect of Its Original Creation; Suitable Also for Exhibiting the Goodness and the Purpose of God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 6:2
verses.text: Reward and Punishment Impossible If Man Were Good or Evil Through Necessity and Not Choice.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 6:3
verses.text: But although we shall be understood, from our argument, to be only so affirming man's unshackled power over his will, that what happens to him should be laid to his own charge, and not to God's, yet that you may not object, even now, that he ought not to have been so constituted, since his liberty and power of will might turn out to be injurious, I will first of all maintain that he was rightly so constituted, that I may with the greater confidence commend both his actual constitution, and the additional fact of its being worthy of the Divine Being; the cause which led to man's being created with such a constitution being shown to be the better one.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 6:4
verses.text: Moreover, man thus constituted will be protected by both the goodness of God and by His purpose, both of which are always found in concert in our God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 6:5
verses.text: For His purpose is no purpose without goodness; nor is His goodness goodness without a purpose, except forsooth in the case of Marcion's god, who is purposelessly good, as we have shown.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 6:6
verses.text: Well, then, it was proper that God should be known; it was no doubt a good and reasonable thing.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 6:7
verses.text: Proper also was it that there should be something worthy of knowing God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 6:8
verses.text: What could be found so worthy as the image and likeness of God? This also was undoubtedly good and reasonable.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 6:9
verses.text: Therefore it was proper that (he who is) the image and likeness of God should be formed with a free will and a mastery of himself; so that this very thing—namely, freedom of will and self-command—might be reckoned as the image and likeness of God in him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 6:10
verses.text: For this purpose such an essence was adapted to man as suited this character, even the afflatus of the Deity, Himself free and uncontrolled.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 6:11
verses.text: But if you will take some other view of the case, how came it to pass that man, when in possession of the whole world, did not above all things reign in self-possession—a master over others, a slave to himself?  The goodness of God, then, you can learn from His gracious gift to man, and His purpose from His disposal of all things.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 6:12
verses.text: At present, let God's goodness alone occupy our attention, that which gave so large a gift to man, even the liberty of his will.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 6:13
verses.text: God's purpose claims some other opportunity of treatment, offering as it does instruction of like import.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 6:14
verses.text: Now, God alone is good by nature.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 6:15
verses.text: For He, who has that which is without beginning, has it not by creation, but by nature.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 6:16
verses.text: Man, however, who exists entirely by creation, having a beginning, along with that beginning obtained the form in which he exists; and thus he is not by nature disposed to good, but by creation, not having it as his own attribute to be good, because, (as we have said,) it is not by nature, but by creation, that he is disposed to good, according to the appointment of his good Creator, even the Author of all good.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 6:17
verses.text: In order, therefore, that man might have a goodness of his own, bestowed on him by God, and there might be henceforth in man a property, and in a certain sense a natural attribute of goodness, there was assigned to him in the constitution of his nature, as a formal witness of the goodness which God bestowed upon him, freedom and power of the will, such as should cause good to be performed spontaneously by man, as a property of his own, on the ground that no less than this would be required in the matter of a goodness which was to be voluntarily exercised by him, that is to say, by the liberty of his will, without either favour or servility to the constitution of his nature, so that man should be good just up to this point, if he should display his goodness in accordance with his natural constitution indeed, but still as the result of his will, as a property of his nature; and, by a similar exercise of volition, should show himself to be too strong in defence against evil also (for even this God, of course, foresaw), being free, and master of himself; because, if he were wanting in this prerogative of self-mastery, so as to perform even good by necessity and not will, he would, in the helplessness of his servitude, become subject to the usurpation of evil, a slave as much to evil as to good.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 6:18
verses.text: Entire freedom of will, therefore, was conferred upon him in both tendencies; so that, as master of himself, he might constantly encounter good by spontaneous observance of it, and evil by its spontaneous avoidance; because, were man even otherwise circumstanced, it was yet his bounden duty, in the judgment of God, to do justice according to the motions of his will regarded, of course, as free.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 6:19
verses.text: But the reward neither of good nor of evil could be paid to the man who should be found to have been either good or evil through necessity and not choice.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 6:20
verses.text: In this really lay the law which did not exclude, but rather prove, human liberty by a spontaneous rendering of obedience, or a spontaneous commission of iniquity; so patent was the liberty of man's will for either issue.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 6:21
verses.text: Since, therefore, both the goodness and purpose of God are discovered in the gift to man of freedom in his will, it is not right, after ignoring the original definition of goodness and purpose which it was necessary to determine previous to any discussion of the subject, on subsequent facts to presume to say that God ought not in such a way to have formed man, because the issue was other than what was assumed to be proper for God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 6:22
verses.text: We ought rather, after duly considering that it behoved God so to create man, to leave this consideration unimpaired, and to survey the other aspects of the case.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 6:23
verses.text: It is, no doubt, an easy process for persons who take offence at the fall of man, before they have looked into the facts of his creation, to impute the blame of what happened to the Creator, without any examination of His purpose.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 6:24
verses.text: To conclude:  the goodness of God, then fully considered from the beginning of His works, will be enough to convince us that nothing evil could possibly have come forth from God; and the liberty of man will, after a second thought, show us that it alone is chargeable with the fault which itself committed.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 7:1
verses.text: If God Had Anyhow Checked Man's Liberty, Marcion Would Have Been Ready with Another and Opposite Cavil.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 7:2
verses.text: Man's Fall Foreseen by God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 7:3
verses.text: Provision Made for It Remedially and Consistently with His Truth and Goodness.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 7:4
verses.text: By such a conclusion all is reserved unimpaired to God; both His natural goodness, and the purposes of His governance and foreknowledge, and the abundance of His power.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 7:5
verses.text: You ought, however, to deduct from God's attributes both His supreme earnestness of purpose and most excellent truth in His whole creation, if you would cease to inquire whether anything could have happened against the will of God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 7:6
verses.text: For, while holding this earnestness and truth of the good God, which are indeed capable of proof from the rational creation, you will not wonder at the fact that God did not interfere to prevent the occurrence of what He wished not to happen, in order that He might keep from harm what He wished.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 7:7
verses.text: For, since He had once for all allowed (and, as we have shown, worthily allowed) to man freedom of will and mastery of himself, surely He from His very authority in creation permitted these gifts to be enjoyed: to be enjoyed, too, so far as lay in Himself, according to His own character as God, that is, for good (for who would permit anything hostile to himself?); and, so far as lay in man, according to the impulses of his liberty (for who does not, when giving anything to any one to enjoy, accompany the gift with a permission to enjoy it with all his heart and will?).

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 7:8
verses.text: The necessary consequence, therefore, was, that God must separate from the liberty which He had once for all bestowed upon man (in other words, keep within Himself), both His foreknowledge and power, through which He might have prevented man's falling into danger when attempting wrongly to enjoy his liberty.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 7:9
verses.text: Now, if He had interposed, He would have rescinded the liberty of man's will, which He had permitted with set purpose, and in goodness.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 7:10
verses.text: But, suppose God had interposed; suppose Him to have abrogated man's liberty, by warning him from the tree, and keeping off the subtle serpent from his interview with the woman; would not Marcion then exclaim, What a frivolous, unstable, and faithless Lord, cancelling the gifts He had bestowed!  Why did He allow any liberty of will, if He afterwards withdrew it? Why withdraw it after allowing it? Let Him choose where to brand Himself with error, either in His original constitution of man, or in His subsequent abrogation thereof! If He had checked (man's freedom), would He not then seem to have been rather deceived, through want of foresight into the future? But in giving it full scope, who would not say that He did so in ignorance of the issue of things? God, however, did foreknow that man would make a bad use of his created constitution; and yet what can be so worthy of God as His earnestness of purpose, and the truth of His created works, be they what they may?  Man must see, if he failed to make the most of the good gift he had received, how that he was himself guilty in respect of the law which he did not choose to keep, and not that the Lawgiver was committing a fraud against His own law, by not permitting its injunctions to be fulfilled.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 7:11
verses.text: Whenever you are inclined to indulge in such censure (and it is the most becoming for you) against the Creator, recall gently to your mind in His behalf His earnestness, and endurance, and truth, in having given completeness to His creatures both as rational and good.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 8:1
verses.text: Man, Endued with Liberty, Superior to the Angels, Overcomes Even the Angel Which Lured Him to His Fall, When Repentant and Resuming Obedience to God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 8:2
verses.text: For it was not merely that he might live the natural life that God had produced man, but that he should live virtuously, that is, in relation to God and to His law.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 8:3
verses.text: Accordingly, God gave him to live when he was formed into a living soul; but He charged him to live virtuously when he was required to obey a law.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 8:4
verses.text: So also God shows that man was not constituted for death, by now wishing that he should be restored to life, preferring the sinner's repentance to his death.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 8:5
verses.text: As, therefore, God designed for man a condition of life, so man brought on himself a state of death; and this, too, neither through infirmity nor through ignorance, so that no blame can be imputed to the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 8:6
verses.text: No doubt it was an angel who was the seducer; but then the victim of that seduction was free, and master of himself; and as being the image and likeness of God, was stronger than any angel; and as being, too, the afflatus of the Divine Being, was nobler than that material spirit of which angels were made.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 8:7
verses.text: Who maketh, says he, His angels spirits, and His ministers a flame of fire.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 8:8
verses.text: He would not have made all things subject to man, if he had been too weak for the dominion, and inferior to the angels, to whom He assigned no such subjects; nor would He have put the burden of law upon him, if he had been incapable of sustaining so great a weight; nor, again, would He have threatened with the penalty of death a creature whom He knew to be guiltless on the score of his helplessness:  in short, if He had made him infirm, it would not have been by liberty and independence of will, but rather by the withholding from him these endowments.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 8:9
verses.text: And thus it comes to pass, that even now also, the same human being, the same substance of his soul, the same condition as Adam's, is made conqueror over the same devil by the self-same liberty and power of his will, when it moves in obedience to the laws of God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 9:1
verses.text: Another Cavil Answered, i-e:, the Fall Imputable to God, Because Man's Soul is a Portion of the Spiritual Essence of the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 9:2
verses.text: The Divine Afflatus Not in Fault in the Sin of Man, But the Human Will Which Was Additional to It.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 9:3
verses.text: But, you say, in what way soever the substance of the Creator is found to be susceptible of fault, when the afflatus of God, that is to say, the soul, offends in man, it cannot but be that that fault of the portion is refferible to the original whole.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 9:4
verses.text: Now, to meet this objection, we must explain the nature of the soul.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 9:5
verses.text: We must at the outset hold fast the meaning of the Greek scripture, which has afflatus, not spirit.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 9:6
verses.text: Some interpreters of the Greek, without reflecting on the difference of the words, and careless about their exact meaning, put spirit for afflatus; they thus afford to heretics an opportunity of tarnishing the Spirit of God, that is to say, God Himself, with default.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 9:7
verses.text: And now comes the question.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 9:8
verses.text: Afflatus, observe then, is less than spirit, although it comes from spirit; it is the spirit's gentle breeze, but it is not the spirit.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 9:9
verses.text: Now a breeze is rarer than the wind; and although it proceeds from wind, yet a breeze is not the wind.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 9:10
verses.text: One may call a breeze the image of the spirit.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 9:11
verses.text: In the same manner, man is the image of God, that is, of spirit; for God is spirit.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 9:12
verses.text: Afflatus is therefore the image of the spirit.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 9:13
verses.text: Now the image is not in any case equal to the very thing.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 9:14
verses.text: It is one thing to be like the reality, and another thing to be the reality itself.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 9:15
verses.text: So, although the afflatus is the image of the spirit, it is yet not possible to compare the image of God in such a way, that, because the reality—that is, the spirit, or in other words, the Divine Being—is faultless, therefore the afflatus also, that is to say, the image, ought not by any possibility to have done wrong.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 9:16
verses.text: In this respect will the image be less than the reality, and the afflatus inferior to the spirit, in that, while it possesses beyond doubt the true lineaments of divinity, such as an immortal soul, freedom and its own mastery over itself, foreknowledge in a great degree, reasonableness, capacity of understanding and knowledge, it is even in these respects an image still, and never amounts to the actual power of Deity, nor to absolute exemption from fault,—a property which is only conceded to God, that is, to the reality, and which is simply incompatible with an image.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 9:17
verses.text: An image, although it may express all the lineaments of the reality, is yet wanting in its intrinsic power; it is destitute of motion.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 9:18
verses.text: In like manner, the soul, the image of the spirit, is unable to express the simple power thereof, that is to say, its happy exemption from sinning.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 9:19
verses.text: Were it otherwise, it would not be soul, but spirit; not man, who received a soul, but God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 9:20
verses.text: Besides, to take another view of the matter, not everything which pertains to God will be regarded as God, so that you would not maintain that His afflatus was God, that is, exempt from fault, because it is the breath of God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 9:21
verses.text: And in an act of your own, such as blowing into a flute, you would not thereby make the flute human, although it was your own human breath which you breathed into it, precisely as God breathed of His own Spirit.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 9:22
verses.text: In fact, the Scripture, by expressly saying that God breathed into man's nostrils the breath of life, and that man became thereby a living soul, not a life-giving spirit, has distinguished that soul from the condition of the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 9:23
verses.text: The work must necessarily be distinct from the workman, and it is inferior to him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 9:24
verses.text: The pitcher will not be the potter, although made by the potter; nor in like manner, will the afflatus, because made by the spirit, be on that account the spirit.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 9:25
verses.text: The soul has often been called by the same name as the breath.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 9:26
verses.text: You should also take care that no descent be made from the breath to a still lower quality.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 9:27
verses.text: So you have granted (you say) the infirmity of the soul, which you denied before! Undoubtedly, when you demand for it an equality with God, that is, a freedom from fault, I contend that it is infirm.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 9:28
verses.text: But when the comparison is challenged with an angel, I am compelled to maintain that the head over all things is the stronger of the two, to whom the angels are ministers, who is destined to be the judge of angels, if he shall stand fast in the law of God—an obedience which he refused at first.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 9:29
verses.text: Now this disobedience it was possible for the afflatus of God to commit: it was possible, but it was not proper.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 9:30
verses.text: The possibility lay in its slenderness of nature, as being the breath and not the spirit; the impropriety, however, arose from its power of will, as being free, and not a slave.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 9:31
verses.text: It was furthermore assisted by the warning against committing sin under the threat of incurring death, which was meant to be a support for its slender nature, and a direction for its liberty of choice.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 9:32
verses.text: So that the soul can no longer appear to have sinned, because it has an affinity with God, that is to say, through the afflatus, but rather through that which was an addition to its nature, that is, through its free-will, which was indeed given to it by God in accordance with His purpose and reason, but recklessly employed by man according as he chose.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 9:33
verses.text: This, then, being the case, the entire course of God's action is purged from all imputation to evil.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 9:34
verses.text: For the liberty of the will will not retort its own wrong on Him by whom it was bestowed, but on him by whom it was improperly used.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 9:35
verses.text: What is the evil, then, which you want to impute to the Creator?  If it is man's sin, it will not be God's fault, because it is man's doing; nor is that Being to be regarded as the author of the sin, who turns out to be its forbidder, nay, its condemner.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 9:36
verses.text: If death is the evil, death will not give the reproach of being its own author to Him who threatened it, but to him who despised it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 9:37
verses.text: For by his contempt he introduced it, which assuredly would not have appeared had man not despised it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 10:1
verses.text: Another Cavil Met, i-e:, the Devil Who Instigated Man to Sin Himself the Creature of God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 10:2
verses.text: Nay, the Primeval Cherub Only Was God's Work.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 10:3
verses.text: The Devilish Nature Superadded by Wilfulness.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 10:4
verses.text: In Man's Recovery the Devil is Vanquished in a Conflict on His Own Ground.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 10:5
verses.text: If, however, you choose to transfer the account of evil from man to the devil as the instigator of sin, and in this way, too, throw the blame on the Creator, inasmuch as He created the devil,—for He maketh those spiritual beings, the angels—then it will follow that what was made, that is to say, the angel, will belong to Him who made it; while that which was not made by God, even the devil, or accuser, cannot but have been made by itself; and this by false detraction from God: first, how that God had forbidden them to eat of every tree; then, with the pretence that they should not die if they ate; thirdly, as if God grudged them the property of divinity.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 10:6
verses.text: Now, whence originated this malice of lying and deceit towards man, and slandering of God? Most certainly not from God, who made the angel good after the fashion of His good works.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 10:7
verses.text: Indeed, before he became the devil, he stands forth the wisest of creatures; and wisdom is no evil.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 10:8
verses.text: If you turn to the prophecy of Ezekiel, you will at once perceive that this angel was both by creation good and by choice corrupt.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 10:9
verses.text: For in the person of the prince of Tyre it is said in reference to the devil: "Moreover, the word of the Lord came unto me, saying, Son of man, take up a lamentation upon the king of Tyrus, and say unto him, Thus saith the Lord God: Thou sealest up the sum, full of wisdom, perfect in beauty" (this belongs to him as the highest of the angels, the archangel, the wisest of all); "amidst the delights of the paradise of thy God wast thou born" (for it was there, where God had made the angels in a shape which resembled the figure of animals).

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 10:10
verses.text: "Every precious stone was thy covering, the sardius, the topaz, and the diamond, the beryl, the onyx, and the jasper, the sapphire, the emerald, and the carbuncle; and with gold hast thou filled thy barns and thy treasuries.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 10:11
verses.text: From the day when thou wast created, when I set thee, a cherub, upon the holy mountain of God, thou wast in the midst of stones of fire, thou wast irreproachable in thy days, from the day of thy creation, until thine iniquities were discovered.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 10:12
verses.text: By the abundance of thy merchandise thou hast filled thy storehouses, and thou hast sinned," etc.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 10:13
verses.text: This description, it is manifest, properly belongs to the transgression of the angel, and not to the prince's: for none among human beings was either born in the paradise of God, not even Adam himself, who was rather translated thither; nor placed with a cherub upon God's holy mountain, that is to say, in the heights of heaven, from which the Lord testifies that Satan fell; nor detained amongst the stones of fire, and the flashing rays of burning constellations, whence Satan was cast down like lightning.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 10:14
verses.text: No, it is none else than the very author of sin who was denoted in the person of a sinful man: he was once irreproachable, at the time of his creation, formed for good by God, as by the good Creator of irreproachable creatures, and adorned with every angelic glory, and associated with God, good with the Good; but afterwards of his own accord removed to evil.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 10:15
verses.text: From the day when thine iniquities, says he, were discovered,—attributing to him those injuries wherewith he injured man when he was expelled from his allegiance to God,—even from that time did he sin, when he propagated his sin, and thereby plied "the abundance of his merchandise," that is, of his Wickedness, even the tale of his transgressions, because he was himself as a spirit no less (than man) created, with the faculty of free-will.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 10:16
verses.text: For God would in nothing fail to endow a being who was to be next to Himself with a liberty of this kind.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 10:17
verses.text: Nevertheless, by precondemning him, God testified that he had departed from the condition of his created nature, through his own lusting after the wickedness which was spontaneously conceived within him; and at the same time, by conceding a permission for the operation of his designs, He acted consistently with the purpose of His own goodness, deferring the devil's destruction for the self-same reason as He postponed the restitution of man.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 10:18
verses.text: For He afforded room for a conflict, wherein man might crush his enemy with the same freedom of his will as had made him succumb to him (proving that the fault was all his own, not God's), and so worthily recover his salvation by a victory; wherein also the devil might receive a more bitter punishment, through being vanquished by him whom he had previously injured; and wherein God might be discovered to be so much the more good, as waiting for man to return from his present life to a more glorious paradise, with a right to pluck of the tree of life.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 11:1
verses.text: If, After Man's Sin, God Exercised His Attribute of Justice and Judgment, This Was Compatible with His Goodness, and Enhances the True Idea of the Perfection of God's Character.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 11:2
verses.text: Up to the fall of man, therefore, from the beginning God was simply good; after that He became a judge both severe and, as the Marcionites will have it, cruel.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 11:3
verses.text: Woman is at once condemned to bring forth in sorrow, and to serve her husband, although before she had heard without pain the increase of her race proclaimed with the blessing, Increase and multiply, and although she had been destined to be a help and not a slave to her male partner.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 11:4
verses.text: Immediately the earth is also cursed, which before was blessed.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 11:5
verses.text: Immediately spring up briers and thorns, where once had grown grass, and herbs, and fruitful trees.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 11:6
verses.text: Immediately arise sweat and labour for bread, where previously on every tree was yielded spontaneous food and untilled nourishment.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 11:7
verses.text: Thenceforth it is "man to the ground," and not as before, "from the ground"; to death thenceforth, but before, to life; thenceforth with coats of skins, but before, nakedness without a blush.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 11:8
verses.text: Thus God's prior goodness was from nature, His subsequent severity from a cause.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 11:9
verses.text: The one was innate, the other accidental; the one His own, the other adapted; the one issuing from Him, the other admitted by Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 11:10
verses.text: But then nature could not have rightly permitted His goodness to have gone on inoperative, nor the cause have allowed His severity to have escaped in disguise or concealment.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 11:11
verses.text: God provided the one for Himself, the other for the occasion.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 11:12
verses.text: You should now set about showing also that the position of a judge is allied with evil, who have been dreaming of another god as a purely good one—solely because you cannot understand the Deity to be a judge; although we have proved God to be also a judge.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 11:13
verses.text: Or if not a judge, at any rate a perverse and useless originator of a discipline which is not to be vindicated—in other words, not to be judged.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 11:14
verses.text: You do not, however, disprove God's being a judge, who have no proof to show that He is a judge.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 11:15
verses.text: You will undoubtedly have to accuse justice herself, which provides the judge, or else to reckon her among the species of evil, that is, to add injustice to the titles of goodness.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 11:16
verses.text: But then justice is an evil, if injustice is a good.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 11:17
verses.text: And yet you are forced to declare injustice to be one of the worst of things, and by the same rule are constrained to class justice amongst the most excellent.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 11:18
verses.text: Since there is nothing hostile to evil which is not good, and no enemy of good which is not evil.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 11:19
verses.text: It follows, then, that as injustice is an evil, so in the same degree is justice a good.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 11:20
verses.text: Nor should it be regarded as simply a species of goodness, but as the practical observance of it, because goodness (unless justice be so controlled as to be just) will not be goodness, if it be unjust.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 11:21
verses.text: For nothing is good which is unjust; while everything, on the other hand, which is just is good.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 12:1
verses.text: The Attributes of Goodness and Justice Should Not Be Separated.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 12:2
verses.text: They are Compatible in the True God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 12:3
verses.text: The Function of Justice in the Divine Being Described.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 12:4
verses.text: Since, therefore, there is this union and agreement between goodness and justice, you cannot prescribe their separation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 12:5
verses.text: With what face will you determine the separation of your two Gods, regarding in their separate condition one as distinctively the good God, and the other as distinctively the just God? Where the just is, there also exists the good.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 12:6
verses.text: In short, from the very first the Creator was both good and also just.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 12:7
verses.text: And both His attributes advanced together.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 12:8
verses.text: His goodness created, His justice arranged, the world; and in this process it even then decreed that the world should be formed of good materials, because it took counsel with goodness.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 12:9
verses.text: The work of justice is apparent, in the separation which was pronounced between light and darkness, between day and night, between heaven and earth, between the water above and the water beneath, between the gathering together of the sea and the mass of the dry land, between the greater lights and the lesser, between the luminaries of the day and those of the night, between male and female, between the tree of knowledge of death and of life, between the world and paradise, between the aqueous and the earth-born animals.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 12:10
verses.text: As goodness conceived all things, so did justice discriminate them.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 12:11
verses.text: With the determination of the latter, everything was arranged and set in order.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 12:12
verses.text: Every site and quality of the elements, their effect, motion, and state, the rise and setting of each, are the judicial determinations of the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 12:13
verses.text: Do not suppose that His function as a judge must be defined as beginning when evil began, and so tarnish His justice with the cause of evil.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 12:14
verses.text: By such considerations, then, do we show that this attribute advanced in company with goodness, the author of all things,—worthy of being herself, too, deemed innate and natural, and not as accidentally accruing to God, inasmuch as she was found to be in Him, her Lord, the arbiter of His works.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 13:1
verses.text: Further Description of the Divine Justice; Since the Fall of Man It Has Regulated the Divine Goodness.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 13:2
verses.text: God's Claims on Our Love and Our Fear Reconciled.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 13:3
verses.text: But yet, when evil afterwards broke out, and the goodness of God began now to have an adversary to contend against, God's justice also acquired another function, even that of directing His goodness according to men's application for it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 13:4
verses.text: And this is the result: the divine goodness, being interrupted in that free course whereby God was spontaneously good, is now dispensed according to the deserts of every man; it is offered to the worthy, denied to the unworthy, taken away from the unthankful, and also avenged on all its enemies.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 13:5
verses.text: Thus the entire office of justice in this respect becomes an agency for goodness: whatever it condemns by its judgment, whatever it chastises by its condemnation, whatever (to use your phrase) it ruthlessly pursues, it, in fact, benefits with good instead of injuring.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 13:6
verses.text: Indeed, the fear of judgment contributes to good, not to evil.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 13:7
verses.text: For good, now contending with an enemy, was not strong enough to recommend itself by itself alone.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 13:8
verses.text: At all events, if it could do so much, it could not keep its ground; for it had lost its impregnability through the foe, unless some power of fear supervened, such as might compel the very unwilling to seek after good, and take care of it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 13:9
verses.text: But who, when so many incentives to evil were assailing him, would desire that good, which he could despise with impunity? Who, again, would take care of what he could lose without danger? You read how broad is the road to evil, how thronged in comparison with the opposite:  would not all glide down that road were there nothing in it to fear? We dread the Creator's tremendous threats, and yet scarcely turn away from evil.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 13:10
verses.text: What, if He threatened not? Will you call this justice an evil, when it is all unfavourable to evil? Will you deny it to be a good, when it has its eye towards good? What sort of being ought you to wish God to be? Would it be right to prefer that He should be such, that sins might flourish under Him, and the devil make mock at Him? Would you suppose Him to be a good God, who should be able to make a man worse by security in sin? Who is the author of good, but He who also requires it? In like manner who is a stranger to evil, except Him who is its enemy? Who its enemy, besides Him who is its conqueror? Who else its conqueror, than He who is its punisher? Thus God is wholly good, because in all things He is on the side of good.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 13:11
verses.text: In fact, He is omnipotent, because able both to help and to hurt.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 13:12
verses.text: Merely to profit is a comparatively small matter, because it can do nothing else than a good turn.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 13:13
verses.text: From such a conduct with what confidence can I hope for good, if this is its only ability? How can I follow after the reward of innocence, if I have no regard to the requital of wrong-doing? I must needs have my doubts whether he might not fail in recompensing one or other alternative, who was unequal in his resources to meet both.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 13:14
verses.text: Thus far, then, justice is the very fulness of the Deity Himself, manifesting God as both a perfect father and a perfect master: a father in His mercy, a master in His discipline; a father in the mildness of His power, a master in its severity; a father who must be loved with dutiful affection, a master who must needs be feared; be loved, because He prefers mercy to sacrifice; be feared because He dislikes sin; be loved, because He prefers the sinner's repentance to his death; be feared, because He dislikes the sinners who do not repent.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 13:15
verses.text: Accordingly, the divine law enjoins duties in respect of both these attributes: Thou shalt love God, and, Thou shalt fear God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 13:16
verses.text: It proposed one for the obedient man, the other for the transgressor.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 14:1
verses.text: Evil of Two Kinds, Penal and Criminal.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 14:2
verses.text: It is Not of the Latter Sort that God is the Author, But Only of the Former, Which are Penal, and Included in His Justice.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 14:3
verses.text: On all occasions does God meet you: it is He who smites, but also heals; who kills, but also makes alive; who humbles, and yet exalts; who "creates evil," but also "makes peace;"—so that from these very (contrasts of His providence) I may get an answer to the heretics.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 14:4
verses.text: Behold, they say, how He acknowledges Himself to be the creator of evil in the passage, "It is I who create evil".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 14:5
verses.text: They take a word whose one form reduces to confusion and ambiguity two kinds of evils (because both sins and punishments are called evils), and will have Him in every passage to be understood as the creator of all evil things, in order that He may be designated the author of evil.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 14:6
verses.text: We, on the contrary, distinguish between the two meanings of the word in question, and, by separating evils of sin from penal evils, mala culpae from mala poenae, confine to each of the two classes its own author,—the devil as the author of the sinful evils (culpae), and God as the creator of penal evils (poenae); so that the one class shall be accounted as morally bad, and the other be classed as the operations of justice passing penal sentences against the evils of sin.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 14:7
verses.text: Of the latter class of evils which are compatible with justice, God is therefore avowedly the creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 14:8
verses.text: They are, no doubt, evil to those by whom they are endured, but still on their own account good, as being just and defensive of good and hostile to sin.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 14:9
verses.text: In this respect they are, moreover, worthy of God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 14:10
verses.text: Else prove them to be unjust, in order to show them deserving of a place in the sinful class, that is to say, evils of injustice; because if they turn out to belong to justice, they will be no longer evil things, but good—evil only to the bad, by whom even directly good things are condemned as evil.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 14:11
verses.text: In this case, you must decide that man, although the wilful contemner of the divine law, unjustly bore the doom which he would like to have escaped; that the wickedness of those days was unjustly smitten by the deluge, afterwards by the fire (of Sodom); that Egypt, although most depraved and superstitious, and, worse still, the harasser of its guest-population, was unjustly stricken with the chastisement of its ten plagues.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 14:12
verses.text: God hardens the heart of Pharaoh.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 14:13
verses.text: He deserved, however, to be influenced to his destruction, who had already denied God, already in his pride so often rejected His ambassadors, accumulated heavy burdens on His people, and (to sum up all) as an Egyptian, had long been guilty before God of Gentile idolatry, worshipping the ibis and the crocodile in preference to the living God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 14:14
verses.text: Even His own people did God visit in their ingratitude.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 14:15
verses.text: Against young lads, too, did He send forth bears, for their irreverence to the prophet.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 15:1
verses.text: The Severity of God Compatible with Reason and Justice.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 15:2
verses.text: When Inflicted, Not Meant to Be Arbitrary, But Remedial.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 15:3
verses.text: Consider well, then, before all things the justice of the Judge; and if its purpose be clear, then the severity thereof, and the operations of the severity in its course, will appear compatible with reason and justice.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 15:4
verses.text: Now, that we may not linger too long on the point, (I would challenge you to) assert the other reasons also, that you may condemn the Judge's sentences; extenuate the delinquencies of the sinner, that you may blame his judicial conviction.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 15:5
verses.text: Never mind censuring the Judge; rather prove Him to be an unjust one.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 15:6
verses.text: Well, then, even though He required the sins of the fathers at the hands of the children, the hardness of the people made such remedial measures necessary for them, in order that, having their posterity in view, they might obey the divine law.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 15:7
verses.text: For who is there that feels not a greater care for his children than for himself? Again, if the blessing of the fathers was destined likewise for their offspring, previous to any merit on the part of these, why might not the guilt of the fathers also redound to their children? As was the grace, so was the offence; so that the grace and the offence equally ran down through the whole race, with the reservation, indeed, of that subsequent ordinance by which it became possible to refrain from saying, that "the fathers had eaten a sour grape, and the children's teeth were set on edge:" in other words, that the father should not bear the iniquity of the son, nor the son the iniquity of the father, but that every man should be chargeable with his own sin; so that the harshness of the law having been reduced after the hardness of the people, justice was no longer to judge the race, but individuals.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 15:8
verses.text: If, however, you accept the gospel of truth, you will discover on whom recoils the sentence of the Judge, when requiting on sons the sins of their fathers, even on those who had been (hardened enough) to imprecate spontaneously on themselves this condemnation: "His blood be on us, and on our children".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 15:9
verses.text: This, therefore, the providence of God has ordered throughout its course, even as it had heard it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 16:1
verses.text: To the Severity of God There Belong Accessory Qualities, Compatible with Justice.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 16:2
verses.text: If Human Passions are Predicated of God, They Must Not Be Measured on the Scale of Human Imperfection.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 16:3
verses.text: Even His severity then is good, because just: when the judge is good, that is just.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 16:4
verses.text: Other qualities likewise are good, by means of which the good work of a good severity runs out its course, whether wrath, or jealousy, or sternness.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 16:5
verses.text: For all these are as indispensable to severity as severity is to justice.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 16:6
verses.text: The shamelessness of an age, which ought to have been reverent, had to be avenged.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 16:7
verses.text: Accordingly, qualities which pertain to the judge, when they are actually free from blame, as the judge himself is, will never be able to be charged upon him as a fault.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 16:8
verses.text: What would be said, if, when you thought the doctor necessary, you were to find fault with his instruments, because they cut, or cauterize, or amputate, or tighten; whereas there could be no doctor of any value without his professional tools?  Censure, if you please, the practitioner who cuts badly, amputates clumsily, is rash in his cautery; and even blame his implements as rough tools of his art.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 16:9
verses.text: Your conduct is equally unreasonable, when you allow indeed that God is a judge, but at the same time destroy those operations and dispositions by which He discharges His judicial functions.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 16:10
verses.text: We are taught God by the prophets, and by Christ, not by the philosophers nor by Epicurus.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 16:11
verses.text: We who believe that God really lived on earth, and took upon Him the low estate of human form, for the purpose of man's salvation, are very far from thinking as those do who refuse to believe that God cares for anything.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 16:12
verses.text: Whence has found its way to the heretics an argument of this kind:  If God is angry, and jealous, and roused, and grieved, He must therefore be corrupted, and must therefore die.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 16:13
verses.text: Fortunately, however, it is a part of the creed of Christians even to believe that God did die, and yet that He is alive for evermore.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 16:14
verses.text: Superlative is their folly, who prejudge divine things from human; so that, because in man's corrupt condition there are found passions of this description, therefore there must be deemed to exist in God also sensations of the same kind.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 16:15
verses.text: Discriminate between the natures, and assign to them their respective senses, which are as diverse as their natures require, although they seem to have a community of designations.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 16:16
verses.text: We read, indeed, of God's right hand, and eyes, and feet: these must not, however, be compared with those of human beings, because they are associated in one and the same name.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 16:17
verses.text: Now, as great as shall be the difference between the divine and the human body, although their members pass under identical names, so great will also be the diversity between the divine and the human soul, notwithstanding that their sensations are designated by the same names.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 16:18
verses.text: These sensations in the human being are rendered just as corrupt by the corruptibility of man's substance, as in God they are rendered incorruptible by the incorruption of the divine essence.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 16:19
verses.text: Do you really believe the Creator to be God? By all means, is your reply.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 16:20
verses.text: How then do you suppose that in God there is anything human, and not that all is divine?  Him whom you do not deny to be God, you confess to be not human; because, when you confess Him to be God, you have, in fact, already determined that He is undoubtedly diverse from every sort of human conditions.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 16:21
verses.text: Furthermore, although you allow, with others, that man was inbreathed by God into a living soul, not God by man, it is yet palpably absurd of you to be placing human characteristics in God rather than divine ones in man, and clothing God in the likeness of man, instead of man in the image of God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 16:22
verses.text: And this, therefore, is to be deemed the likeness of God in man, that the human soul have the same emotions and sensations as God, although they are not of the same kind; differing as they do both in their conditions and their issues according to their nature.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 16:23
verses.text: Then, again, with respect to the opposite sensations,—I mean meekness, patience, mercy, and the very parent of them all, goodness,—why do you form your opinion of the divine displays of these (from the human qualities)? For we indeed do not possess them in perfection, because it is God alone who is perfect.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 16:24
verses.text: So also in regard to those others,—namely, anger and irritation, we are not affected by them in so happy a manner, because God alone is truly happy, by reason of His property of incorruptibility.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 16:25
verses.text: Angry He will possibly be, but not irritated, nor dangerously tempted; He will be moved, but not subverted.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 16:26
verses.text: All appliances He must needs use, because of all contingencies; as many sensations as there are causes: anger because of the wicked, and indignation because of the ungrateful, and jealousy because of the proud, and whatsoever else is a hinderance to the evil.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 16:27
verses.text: So, again, mercy on account of the erring, and patience on account of the impenitent, and pre-eminent resources on account of the meritorious, and whatsoever is necessary to the good.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 16:28
verses.text: All these affections He is moved by in that peculiar manner of His own, in which it is profoundly fit that He should be affected; and it is owing to Him that man is also similarly affected in a way which is equally his own.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 17:1
