verses.text: Trace God's Government in History and in His Precepts, and You Will Find It Full of His Goodness.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 17:2
verses.text: These considerations show that the entire order of God as Judge is an operative one, and (that I may express myself in worthier words) protective of His Catholic and supreme goodness, which, removed as it is from judiciary emotions, and pure in its own condition, the Marcionites refuse to acknowledge to be in one and the same Deity, "raining on the just and on the unjust, and making His sun to rise on the evil and on the good,"—a bounty which no other god at all exercises.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 17:3
verses.text: It is true that Marcion has been bold enough to erase from the gospel this testimony of Christ to the Creator; but yet the world itself is inscribed with the goodness of its Maker, and the inscription is read by each man's conscience.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 17:4
verses.text: Nay, this very long-suffering of the Creator will tend to the condemnation of Marcion; that patience, (I mean,) which waits for the sinner's repentance rather than his death, which prefers mercy to sacrifice, averting from the Ninevites the ruin which had been already denounced against them, and vouchsafing to Hezekiah's tears an extension of his life, and restoring his kingly state to the monarch of Babylon after his complete repentance; that mercy, too, which conceded to the devotion of the people the son of Saul when about to die, and gave free forgiveness to David on his confessing his sins against the house of Uriah; which also restored the house of Israel as often as it condemned it, and addressed to it consolation no less frequently than reproof.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 17:5
verses.text: Do not therefore look at God simply as Judge, but turn your attention also to examples of His conduct as the Most Good.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 17:6
verses.text: Noting Him, as you do, when He takes vengeance, consider Him likewise when He shows mercy.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 17:7
verses.text: In the scale, against His severity place His gentleness.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 17:8
verses.text: When you shall have discovered both qualities to co-exist in the Creator, you will find in Him that very circumstance which induces you to think there is another God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 17:9
verses.text: Lastly, come and examine into His doctrine, discipline, precepts, and counsels.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 17:10
verses.text: You will perhaps say that there are equally good prescriptions in human laws.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 17:11
verses.text: But Moses and God existed before all your Lycurguses and Solons.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 17:12
verses.text: There is not one after-age which does not take from primitive sources.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 17:13
verses.text: At any rate, my Creator did not learn from your God to issue such commandments as: Thou shalt not kill; thou shalt not commit adultery; thou shalt not steal; thou shalt not bear false witness; thou shalt not covet what is thy neighbour's; honour thy father and thy mother; and, thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 17:14
verses.text: To these prime counsels of innocence, chastity, and justice, and piety, are also added prescriptions of humanity, as when every seventh year slaves are released for liberty; when at the same period the land is spared from tillage; a place is also granted to the needy; and from the treading ox's mouth the muzzle is removed, for the enjoyment of the fruit of his labour before him, in order that kindness first shown in the case of animals might be raised from such rudiments to the refreshment of men.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 18:1
verses.text: Some of God's Laws Defended as Good, Which the Marcionites Impeached, Such as the Lex Talionis.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 18:2
verses.text: Useful Purposes in a Social and Moral Point of View of This, and Sundry Other Enactments.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 18:3
verses.text: But what parts of the law can I defend as good with a greater confidence than those which heresy has shown such a longing for?—as the statute of retaliation, requiring eye for eye, tooth for tooth, and stripe for stripe.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 18:4
verses.text: Now there is not here any smack of a permission to mutual injury; but rather, on the whole, a provision for restraining violence.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 18:5
verses.text: To a people which was very obdurate, and wanting in faith towards God, it might seem tedious, and even incredible, to expect from God that vengeance which was subsequently to be declared by the prophet: "Vengeance is mine; I will repay, saith the Lord".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 18:6
verses.text: Therefore, in the meanwhile, the commission of wrong was to be checked by the fear of a retribution immediately to happen; and so the permission of this retribution was to be the prohibition of provocation, that a stop might thus be put to all hot-blooded injury, whilst by the permission of the second the first is prevented by fear, and by this deterring of the first the second fails to be committed.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 18:7
verses.text: By the same law another result is also obtained, even the more ready kindling of the fear of retaliation by reason of the very savour of passion which is in it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 18:8
verses.text: There is no more bitter thing, than to endure the very suffering which you have inflicted upon others.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 18:9
verses.text: When, again, the law took somewhat away from men's food, by pronouncing unclean certain animals which were once blessed, you should understand this to be a measure for encouraging continence, and recognise in it a bridle imposed on that appetite which, while eating angels' food, craved after the cucumbers and melons of the Egyptians.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 18:10
verses.text: Recognise also therein a precaution against those companions of the appetite, even lust and luxury, which are usually chilled by the chastening of the appetite.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 18:11
verses.text: For "the people sat down to eat and to drink, and rose up to play".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 18:12
verses.text: Furthermore, that an eager wish for money might be restrained, so far as it is caused by the need of food, the desire for costly meat and drink was taken out of their power.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 18:13
verses.text: Lastly, in order that man might be more readily educated by God for fasting, he was accustomed to such articles of food as were neither plentiful nor sumptuous, and not likely to pamper the appetite of the luxurious.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 18:14
verses.text: Of course the Creator deserved all the greater blame, because it was from His own people that He took away food, rather than from the more ungrateful Marcionites.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 18:15
verses.text: As for the burdensome sacrifices also, and the troublesome scrupulousness of their ceremonies and oblations, no one should blame them, as if God specially required them for Himself: for He plainly asks, "To what purpose is the multitude of your sacrifices unto me?" and, "Who hath required them at your hand?" But he should see herein a careful provision on God's part, which showed His wish to bind to His own religion a people who were prone to idolatry and transgression by that kind of services wherein consisted the superstition of that period; that He might call them away therefrom, while requesting it to be performed to Himself, as if He desired that no sin should be committed in making idols.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 19:1
verses.text: The Minute Prescriptions of the Law Meant to Keep the People Dependent on God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 19:2
verses.text: The Prophets Sent by God in Pursuance of His Goodness.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 19:3
verses.text: Many Beautiful Passages from Them Quoted in Illustration of This Attribute.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 19:4
verses.text: But even in the common transactions of life, and of human intercourse at home and in public, even to the care of the smallest vessels, He in every possible manner made distinct arrangement; in order that, when they everywhere encountered these legal instructions, they might not be at any moment out of the sight of God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 19:5
verses.text: For what could better tend to make a man happy, than having "his delight in the law of the Lord?" "In that law would he meditate day and night".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 19:6
verses.text: It was not in severity that its Author promulgated this law, but in the interest of the highest benevolence, which rather aimed at subduing the nation's hardness of heart, and by laborious services hewing out a fealty which was (as yet) untried in obedience:  for I purposely abstain from touching on the mysterious senses of the law, considered in its spiritual and prophetic relation, and as abounding in types of almost every variety and sort.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 19:7
verses.text: It is enough at present, that it simply bound a man to God, so that no one ought to find fault with it, except him who does not choose to serve God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 19:8
verses.text: To help forward this beneficent, not onerous, purpose of the law, the prophets were also ordained by the self-same goodness of God, teaching precepts worthy of God, how that men should "cease to do evil, learn to do well, seek judgment, judge the fatherless, and plead for the widow:" be fond of the divine expostulations: avoid contact with the wicked: "let the oppressed go free:" dismiss the unjust sentence, "deal their bread to the hungry; bring the outcast into their house; cover the naked, when they see him; nor hide themselves from their own flesh and kin:" "keep their tongue from evil, and their lips from speaking guile: depart from evil, and do good; seek peace, and pursue it:" be angry, and sin not; that is, not persevere in anger, or be enraged: "walk not in the counsel of the ungodly; nor stand in the way of sinners; nor sit in the seat of the scornful".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 19:9
verses.text: Where then?  "Behold, how good and how pleasant it is for brethren to dwell together in unity;" meditating (as they do) day and night in the law of the Lord, because "it is better to trust in the Lord than to put confidence in man; better to hope in the Lord than in man".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 19:10
verses.text: For what recompense shall man receive from God? "He shall be like a tree planted by the rivers of water, that bringeth forth his fruit in his season; his leaf also shall not wither, and whatsoever he doeth shall prosper".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 19:11
verses.text: "He that hath clean hands and a pure heart, who hath not taken God's name in vain, nor sworn deceitfully to his neighbour, he shall receive blessing from the Lord, and mercy from the God of his salvation".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 19:12
verses.text: "For the eyes of the Lord are upon them that fear Him, upon them that hope in His mercy, to deliver their souls from death," even eternal death, "and to nourish them in their hunger," that is, after eternal life.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 19:13
verses.text: "Many are the afflictions of the righteous, but the Lord delivereth them out of them all".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 19:14
verses.text: "Precious in the sight of the Lord is the death of His saints".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 19:15
verses.text: "The Lord keepeth all their bones; not one of them shall be broken".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 19:16
verses.text: The Lord will redeem the souls of His servants.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 19:17
verses.text: We have adduced these few quotations from a mass of the Creator's Scriptures; and no more, I suppose, are wanted to prove Him to be a most good God, for they sufficiently indicate both the precepts of His goodness and the first-fruits thereof.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 20:1
verses.text: The Marcionites Charged God with Having Instigated the Hebrews to Spoil the Egyptians.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 20:2
verses.text: Defence of the Divine Dispensation in that Matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 20:3
verses.text: But these "saucy cuttles" (of heretics) under the figure of whom the law about things to be eaten prohibited this very kind of piscatory aliment, as soon as they find themselves confuted, eject the black venom of their blasphemy, and so spread about in all directions the object which (as is now plain) they severally have in view, when they put forth such assertions and protestations as shall obscure and tarnish the rekindled light of the Creator's bounty.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 20:4
verses.text: We will, however, follow their wicked design, even through these black clouds, and drag to light their tricks of dark calumny, laying to the Creator's charge with especial emphasis the fraud and theft of gold and silver which the Hebrews were commanded by Him to practise against the Egyptians.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 20:5
verses.text: Come, unhappy heretic, I cite even you as a witness; first look at the case of the two nations, and then you will form a judgment of the Author of the command.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 20:6
verses.text: The Egyptians put in a claim on the Hebrews for these gold and silver vessels.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 20:7
verses.text: The Hebrews assert a counter claim, alleging that by the bond of their respective fathers, attested by the written engagement of both parties, there were due to them the arrears of that laborious slavery of theirs, for the bricks they had so painfully made, and the cities and palaces which they had built.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 20:8
verses.text: What shall be your verdict, you discoverer of the most good God? That the Hebrews must admit the fraud, or the Egyptians the compensation? For they maintain that thus has the question been settled by the advocates on both sides, of the Egyptians demanding their vessels, and the Hebrews claiming the requital of their labours.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 20:9
verses.text: But for all they say, the Egyptians justly renounced their restitution-claim then and there; while the Hebrews to this day, in spite of the Marcionites, re-assert their demand for even greater damages, insisting that, however large was their loan of the gold and silver, it would not be compensation enough, even if the labour of six hundred thousand men should be valued at only "a farthing" a day a piece.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 20:10
verses.text: Which, however, were the more in number—those who claimed the vessel, or those who dwelt in the palaces and cities? Which, too, the greater—the grievance of the Egyptians against the Hebrews, or "the favour" which they displayed towards them? Were free men reduced to servile labour, in order that the Hebrews might simply proceed against the Egyptians by action at law for injuries; or in order that their officers might on their benches sit and exhibit their backs and shoulders shamefully mangled by the fierce application of the scourge? It was not by a few plates and cup—in all cases the property, no doubt, of still fewer rich men—that any one would pronounce that compensation should have been awarded to the Hebrews, but both by all the resources of these and by the contributions of all the people.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 20:11
verses.text: If, therefore, the case of the Hebrews be a good one, the Creator's case must likewise be a good one; that is to say, his command, when He both made the Egyptians unconsciously grateful, and also gave His own people their discharge in full at the time of their migration by the scanty comfort of a tacit requital of their long servitude.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 20:12
verses.text: It was plainly less than their due which He commanded to be exacted.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 20:13
verses.text: The Egyptians ought to have given back their men-children also to the Hebrews.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 21:1
verses.text: The Law of the Sabbath-Day Explained.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 21:2
verses.text: The Eight Days' Procession Around Jericho.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 21:3
verses.text: The Gathering of Sticks a Violation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 21:4
verses.text: Similarly on other points also, you reproach Him with fickleness and instability for contradictions in His commandments, such as that He forbade work to be done on Sabbath-days, and yet at the siege of Jericho ordered the ark to be carried round the walls during eight days; in other words, of course, actually on a Sabbath.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 21:5
verses.text: You do not, however, consider the law of the Sabbath: they are human works, not divine, which it prohibits.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 21:6
verses.text: For it says, "Six days shalt thou labour, and do all thy work; but the seventh day is the Sabbath of the Lord thy God: in it thou shalt not do any work".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 21:7
verses.text: What work?  Of course your own.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 21:8
verses.text: The conclusion is, that from the Sabbath-day He removes those works which He had before enjoined for the six days, that is, your own works; in other words, human works of daily life.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 21:9
verses.text: Now, the carrying around of the ark is evidently not an ordinary daily duty, nor yet a human one; but a rare and a sacred work, and, as being then ordered by the direct precept of God, a divine one.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 21:10
verses.text: And I might fully explain what this signified, were it not a tedious process to open out the forms of all the Creator's proofs, which you would, moreover, probably refuse to allow.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 21:11
verses.text: It is more to the point, if you be confuted on plain matters by the simplicity of truth rather than curious reasoning.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 21:12
verses.text: Thus, in the present instance, there is a clear distinction respecting the Sabbath's prohibition of human labours, not divine ones.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 21:13
verses.text: Accordingly, the man who went and gathered sticks on the Sabbath-day was punished with death.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 21:14
verses.text: For it was his own work which he did; and this the law forbade.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 21:15
verses.text: They, however, who on the Sabbath carried the ark round Jericho, did it with impunity.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 21:16
verses.text: For it was not their own work, but God's, which they executed, and that too, from His express commandment.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 22:1
verses.text: The Brazen Serpent and the Golden Cherubim Were Not Violations of the Second Commandment.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 22:2
verses.text: Their Meaning.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 22:3
verses.text: Likewise, when forbidding the similitude to be made of all things which are in heaven, and in earth, and in the waters, He declared also the reasons, as being prohibitory of all material exhibition of a latent idolatry.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 22:4
verses.text: For He adds: "Thou shalt not bow down to them, nor serve them".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 22:5
verses.text: The form, however, of the brazen serpent which the Lord afterwards commanded Moses to make, afforded no pretext for idolatry, but was meant for the cure of those who were plagued with the fiery serpents.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 22:6
verses.text: I say nothing of what was figured by this cure.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 22:7
verses.text: Thus, too, the golden Cherubim and Seraphim were purely an ornament in the figured fashion of the ark; adapted to ornamentation for reasons totally remote from all condition of idolatry, on account of which the making a likeness is prohibited; and they are evidently not at variance with this law of prohibition, because they are not found in that form of similitude, in reference to which the prohibition is given.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 22:8
verses.text: We have spoken of the rational institution of the sacrifices, as calling off their homage from idols to God; and if He afterwards rejected this homage, saying, "To what purpose is the multitude of your sacrifices unto me?"—He meant nothing else than this to be understood, that He had never really required such homage for Himself.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 22:9
verses.text: For He says, "I will not eat the flesh of bulls;" and in another passage: "The everlasting God shall neither hunger nor thirst".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 22:10
verses.text: Although He had respect to the offerings of Abel, and smelled a sweet savour from the holocaust of Noah, yet what pleasure could He receive from the flesh of sheep, or the odour of burning victims? And yet the simple and God-fearing mind of those who offered what they were receiving from God, both in the way of food and of a sweet smell, was favourably accepted before God, in the sense of respectful homage to God, who did not so much want what was offered, as that which prompted the offering.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 22:11
verses.text: Suppose now, that some dependant were to offer to a rich man or a king, who was in want of nothing, some very insignificant gift, will the amount and quality of the gift bring dishonour to the rich man and the king; or will the consideration of the homage give them pleasure? Were, however, the dependant, either of his own accord or even in compliance with a command, to present to him gifts suitably to his rank, and were he to observe the solemnities due to a king, only without faith and purity of heart, and without any readiness for other acts of obedience, will not that king or rich man consequently exclaim: "To what purpose is the multitude of your sacrifices unto me? I am full of your solemnities, your feast-days, and your Sabbaths".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 22:12
verses.text: By calling them yours, as having been performed after the giver's own will, and not according to the religion of God (since he displayed them as his own, and not as God's), the Almighty in this passage, demonstrated how suitable to the conditions of the case, and how reasonable, was His rejection of those very offerings which He had commanded to be made to Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 23:1
verses.text: God's Purposes in Election and Rejection of the Same Men, Such as King Saul, Explained, in Answer to the Marcionite Cavil.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 23:2
verses.text: Now, although you will have it that He is inconstant in respect of persons, sometimes disapproving where approbation is deserved; or else wanting in foresight, bestowing approbation on men who ought rather to be reprobated, as if He either censured His own past judgments, or could not forecast His future ones; yet nothing is so consistent for even a good judge as both to reject and to choose on the merits of the present moment.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 23:3
verses.text: Saul is chosen, but he is not yet the despiser of the prophet Samuel.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 23:4
verses.text: Solomon is rejected; but he is now become a prey to foreign women, and a slave to the idols of Moab and Sidon.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 23:5
verses.text: What must the Creator do, in order to escape the censure of the Marcionites? Must He prematurely condemn men, who are thus far correct in their conduct, because of future delinquencies? But it is not the mark of a good God to condemn beforehand persons who have not yet deserved condemnation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 23:6
verses.text: Must He then refuse to eject sinners, on account of their previous good deeds? But it is not the characteristic of a just judge to forgive sins in consideration of former virtues which are no longer practised.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 23:7
verses.text: Now, who is so faultless among men, that God could always have him in His choice, and never be able to reject him? Or who, on the other hand, is so void of any good work, that God could reject him for ever, and never be able to choose him? Show me, then, the man who is always good, and he will not be rejected; show me, too, him who is always evil, and he will never be chosen.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 23:8
verses.text: Should, however, the same man, being found on different occasions in the pursuit of both (good and evil) be recompensed in both directions by God, who is both a good and judicial Being, He does not change His judgments through inconstancy or want of foresight, but dispenses reward according to the deserts of each case with a most unwavering and provident decision.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 24:1
verses.text: Instances of God's Repentance, and Notably in the Case of the Ninevites, Accounted for and Vindicated.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 24:2
verses.text: Furthermore, with respect to the repentance which occurs in His conduct, you interpret it with similar perverseness just as if it were with fickleness and improvidence that He repented, or on the recollection of some wrong-doing; because He actually said, "It repenteth me that I have set up Saul to be king," very much as if He meant that His repentance savoured of an acknowledgment of some evil work or error.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 24:3
verses.text: Well, this is not always implied.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 24:4
verses.text: For there occurs even in good works a confession of repentance, as a reproach and condemnation of the man who has proved himself unthankful for a benefit.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 24:5
verses.text: For instance, in this case of Saul, the Creator, who had made no mistake in selecting him for the kingdom, and endowing him with His Holy Spirit, makes a statement respecting the goodliness of his person, how that He had most fitly chosen him as being at that moment the choicest man, so that (as He says) there was not his fellow among the children of Israel.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 24:6
verses.text: Neither was He ignorant how he would afterwards turn out.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 24:7
verses.text: For no one would bear you out in imputing lack of foresight to that God whom, since you do not deny Him to be divine, you allow to be also foreseeing; for this proper attribute of divinity exists in Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 24:8
verses.text: However, He did, as I have said, burden the guilt of Saul with the confession of His own repentance; but as there is an absence of all error and wrong in His choice of Saul, it follows that this repentance is to be understood as upbraiding another rather than as self-incriminating.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 24:9
verses.text: Look here then, say you: I discover a self-incriminating case in the matter of the Ninevites, when the book of Jonah declares, "And God repented of the evil that He had said that He would do unto them; and He did it not".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 24:10
verses.text: In accordance with which Jonah himself says unto the Lord, "Therefore I fled before unto Tarshish; for I knew that Thou art a gracious God and merciful, slow to anger, and of great kindness, and repentest Thee of the evil".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 24:11
verses.text: It is well, therefore, that he premised the attribute of the most good God as most patient over the wicked, and most abundant in mercy and kindness over such as acknowledged and bewailed their sins, as the Ninevites were then doing.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 24:12
verses.text: For if He who has this attribute is the Most Good, you will have first to relinquish that position of yours, that the very contact with evil is incompatible with such a Being, that is, with the most good God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 24:13
verses.text: And because Marcion, too, maintains that a good tree ought not to produce bad fruit; but yet he has mentioned "evil" (in the passage under discussion), which the most good God is incapable of, is there forthcoming any explanation of these "evils," which may render them compatible with even the most Good?  There is.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 24:14
verses.text: We say, in short, that evil in the present case means, not what may be attributed to the Creator's nature as an evil being, but what may be attributed to His power as a judge.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 24:15
verses.text: In accordance with which He declared, "I create evil," and, "I frame evil against you;" meaning not to sinful evils, but avenging ones.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 24:16
verses.text: What sort of stigma pertains to these, congruous as they are with God's judicial character, we have sufficiently explained.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 24:17
verses.text: Now although these are called "evils," they are yet not reprehensible in a judge; nor because of this their name do they show that the judge is evil: so in like manner will this particular evil be understood to be one of this class of judiciary evils, and along with them to be compatible with (God as) a judge.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 24:18
verses.text: The Greeks also sometimes use the word "evils" for troubles and injuries (not malignant ones), as in this passage of yours is also meant.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 24:19
verses.text: Therefore, if the Creator repented of such evil as this, as showing that the creature deserve decondemnation, and ought to be punished for his sin, then, in the present instance no fault of a criminating nature will be imputed to the Creator, for having deservedly and worthily decreed the destruction of a city so full of iniquity.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 24:20
verses.text: What therefore He had justly decreed, having no evil purpose in His decree, He decreed from the principle of justice, not from malevolence.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 24:21
verses.text: Yet He gave it the name of "evil," because of the evil and desert involved in the very suffering itself.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 24:22
verses.text: Then, you will say, if you excuse the evil under name of justice, on the ground that He had justly determined destruction against the people of Nineveh, He must even on this argument be blameworthy, for having repented of an act of justice, which surely should not be repented of.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 24:23
verses.text: Certainly not, my reply is; God will never repent of an act of justice.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 24:24
verses.text: And it now remains that we should understand what God's repentance means.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 24:25
verses.text: For although man repents most frequently on the recollection of a sin, and occasionally even from the unpleasantness of some good action, this is never the case with God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 24:26
verses.text: For, inasmuch as God neither commits sin nor condemns a good action, in so far is there no room in Him for repentance of either a good or an evil deed.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 24:27
verses.text: Now this point is determined for you even in the scripture which we have quoted.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 24:28
verses.text: Samuel says to Saul, "The Lord hath rent the kingdom of Israel from thee this day, and hath given it to a neighbour of thine that is better than thou;" and into two parts shall Israel be divided:  "for He will not turn Himself, nor repent; for He does not repent as a man does".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 24:29
verses.text: According, therefore, to this definition, the divine repentance takes in all cases a different form from that of man, in that it is never regarded as the result of improvidence or of fickleness, or of any condemnation of a good or an evil work.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 24:30
verses.text: What, then, will be the mode of God's repentance? It is already quite clear, if you avoid referring it to human conditions.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 24:31
verses.text: For it will have no other meaning than a simple change of a prior purpose; and this is admissible without any blame even in a man, much more in God, whose every purpose is faultless.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 24:32
verses.text: Now in Greek the word for repentance (μετάνοια ) is formed, not from the confession of a sin, but from a change of mind, which in God we have shown to be regulated by the occurrence of varying circumstances.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 25:1
verses.text: God's Dealings with Adam at the Fall, and with Cain After His Crime, Admirably Explained and Defended.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 25:2
verses.text: It is now high time that I should, in order to meet all objections of this kind, proceed to the explanation and clearing up of the other trifles, weak points, and inconsistencies, as you deemed them.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 25:3
verses.text: God calls out to Adam, Where art thou? as if ignorant where he was; and when he alleged that the shame of his nakedness was the cause (of his hiding himself), He inquired whether he had eaten of the tree, as if He were in doubt.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 25:4
verses.text: By no means; God was neither uncertain about the commission of the sin, nor ignorant of Adam's whereabouts.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 25:5
verses.text: It was certainly proper to summon the offender, who was concealing himself from the consciousness of his sin, and to bring him forth into the presence of his Lord, not merely by the calling out of his name, but with a home-thrust blow at the sin which he had at that moment committed.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 25:6
verses.text: For the question ought not to be read in a merely interrogative tone, Where art thou, Adam? but with an impressive and earnest voice, and with an air of imputation, Oh, Adam, where art thou?—as much as to intimate: thou art no longer here, thou art in perdition—so that the voice is the utterance of One who is at once rebuking and sorrowing.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 25:7
verses.text: But of course some part of paradise had escaped the eye of Him who holds the universe in His hand as if it were a bird's nest, and to whom heaven is a throne and earth a footstool; so that He could not see, before He summoned him forth, where Adam was, both while lurking and when eating of the forbidden fruit!  The wolf or the paltry thief escapes not the notice of the keeper of your vineyard or your garden! And God, I suppose, with His keener vision, from on high was unable to miss the sight of aught which lay beneath Him! Foolish heretic, who treat with scorn so fine an argument of God's greatness and man's instruction! God put the question with an appearance of uncertainty, in order that even here He might prove man to be the subject of a free will in the alternative of either a denial or a confession, and give to him the opportunity of freely acknowledging his transgression, and, so far, of lightening it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 25:8
verses.text: In like manner He inquires of Cain where his brother was, just as if He had not yet heard the blood of Abel crying from the ground, in order that he too might have the opportunity from the same power of the will of spontaneously denying, and to this degree aggravating, his crime; and that thus there might be supplied to us examples of confessing sins rather than of denying them: so that even then was initiated the evangelic doctrine, "By thy words thou shalt be justified, and by thy words thou shalt be condemned".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 25:9
verses.text: Now, although Adam was by reason of his condition under law subject to death, yet was hope preserved to him by the Lord's saying, "Behold, Adam is become as one of us;" that is, in consequence of the future taking of the man into the divine nature.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 25:10
verses.text: Then what follows? "And now, lest he put forth his hand, and take also of the tree of life, (and eat), and live for ever".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 25:11
verses.text: Inserting thus the particle of present time, "And now," He shows that He had made for a time, and at present, a prolongation of man's life.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 25:12
verses.text: Therefore He did not actually curse Adam and Eve, for they were candidates for restoration, and they had been relieved by confession.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 25:13
verses.text: Cain, however, He not only cursed; but when he wished to atone for his sin by death, He even prohibited his dying, so that he had to bear the load of this prohibition in addition to his crime.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 25:14
verses.text: This, then, will prove to be the ignorance of our God, which was simulated on this account, that delinquent man should not be unaware of what he ought to do.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 25:15
verses.text: Coming down to the case of Sodom and Gomorrha, he says: "I will go down now, and see whether they have done altogether according to the cry of it which is come unto me; and if not, I will know".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 25:16
verses.text: Well, was He in this instance also uncertain through ignorance, and desiring to know?  Or was this a necessary tone of utterance, as expressive of a minatory and not a dubious sense, under the colour of an inquiry? If you make merry at God's "going down," as if He could not except by the descent have accomplished His judgment, take care that you do not strike your own God with as hard a blow.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 25:17
verses.text: For He also came down to accomplish what He wished.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 26:1
verses.text: The Oath of God: Its Meaning.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 26:2
verses.text: Moses, When Deprecating God's Wrath Against Israel, a Type of Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 26:3
verses.text: But God also swears.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 26:4
verses.text: Well, is it, I wonder, by the God of Marcion? No, no, he says; a much vainer oath—by Himself! What was He to do, when He knew of no other God; especially when He was swearing to this very point, that besides himself there was absolutely no God?  Is it then of swearing falsely that you convict Him, or of swearing a vain oath? But it is not possible for him to appear to have sworn falsely, when he was ignorant, as you say he was, that there was another God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 26:5
verses.text: For when he swore by that which he knew, he really committed no perjury.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 26:6
verses.text: But it was not a vain oath for him to swear that there was no other God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 26:7
verses.text: It would indeed be a vain oath, if there had been no persons who believed that there were other Gods, like the worshippers of idols then, and the heretics of the present day.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 26:8
verses.text: Therefore He swears by Himself, in order that you may believe God, even when He swears that there is besides Himself no other God at all.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 26:9
verses.text: But you have yourself, O Marcion, compelled God to do this.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 26:10
verses.text: For even so early as then were you foreseen.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 26:11
verses.text: Hence, if He swears both in His promises and His threatenings, and thus extorts faith which at first was difficult, nothing is unworthy of God which causes men to believe in God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 26:12
verses.text: But (you say) God was even then mean enough in His very fierceness, when, in His wrath against the people for their consecration of the calf, He makes this request of His servant Moses: "Let me alone, that my wrath may wax hot against them, and that I may consume them; and I will make of thee a great nation".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 26:13
verses.text: Accordingly, you maintain that Moses is better than his God, as the deprecator, nay the averter, of His anger.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 26:14
verses.text: "For," said he, "Thou shalt not do this; or else destroy me along with them".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 26:15
verses.text: Pitiable are ye also, as well as the people, since you know not Christ, prefigured in the person of Moses as the deprecator of the Father, and the offerer of His own life for the salvation of the people.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 26:16
verses.text: It is enough, however, that the nation was at the instant really given to Moses.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 26:17
verses.text: That which he, as a servant, was able to ask of the Lord, the Lord required of Himself.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 26:18
verses.text: For this purpose did He say to His servant, "Let me alone, that I may consume them," in order that by his entreaty, and by offering himself, he might hinder (the threatened judgment), and that you might by such an instance learn how much privilege is vouchsafed with God to a faithful man and a prophet.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 27:1
verses.text: Other Objections Considered.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 27:2
verses.text: God's Condescension in the Incarnation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 27:3
verses.text: Nothing Derogatory to the Divine Being in This Economy.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 27:4
verses.text: The Divine Majesty Worthily Sustained by the Almighty Father, Never Visible to Man.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 27:5
verses.text: Perverseness of the Marcionite Cavils.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 27:6
verses.text: And now, that I may briefly pass in review the other points which you have thus far been engaged in collecting, as mean, weak, and unworthy, for demolishing the Creator, I will propound them in a simple and definite statement: that God would have been unable to hold any intercourse with men, if He had not taken on Himself the emotions and affections of man, by means of which He could temper the strength of His majesty, which would no doubt have been incapable of endurance to the moderate capacity of man, by such a humiliation as was indeed degrading to Himself, but necessary for man, and such as on this very account became worthy of God, because nothing is so worthy of God as the salvation of man.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 27:7
verses.text: If I were arguing with heathens, I should dwell more at length on this point; although with heretics too the discussion does not stand on very different grounds.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 27:8
verses.text: Inasmuch as ye yourselves have now come to the belief that God moved about in the form and all other circumstances of man's nature, you will of course no longer require to be convinced that God conformed Himself to humanity, but feel yourselves bound by your own faith.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 27:9
verses.text: For if the God (in whom ye believe,) even from His higher condition, prostrated the supreme dignity of His majesty to such a lowliness as to undergo death, even the death of the cross, why can you not suppose that some humiliations are becoming to our God also, only more tolerable than Jewish contumelies, and crosses, and sepulchres? Are these the humiliations which henceforth are to raise a prejudice against Christ (the subject as He is of human passions) being a partaker of that Godhead against which you make the participation in human qualities a reproach? Now we believe that Christ did ever act in the name of God the Father; that He actually from the beginning held intercourse with (men); actually communed with patriarchs and prophets; was the Son of the Creator; was His Word; whom God made His Son by emitting Him from His own self, and thenceforth set Him over every dispensation and (administration of) His will, making Him a little lower than the angels, as is written in David.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 27:10
verses.text: In which lowering of His condition He received from the Father a dispensation in those very respects which you blame as human; from the very beginning learning, even then, (that state of a) man which He was destined in the end to become.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 27:11
verses.text: It is He who descends, He who interrogates, He who demands, He who swears.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 27:12
verses.text: With regard, however, to the Father, the very gospel which is common to us will testify that He was never visible, according to the word of Christ: "No man knoweth the Father, save the Son".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 27:13
verses.text: For even in the Old Testament He had declared, "No man shall see me, and live".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 27:14
verses.text: He means that the Father is invisible, in whose authority and in whose name was He God who appeared as the Son of God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 27:15
verses.text: But with us Christ is received in the person of Christ, because even in this manner is He our God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 27:16
verses.text: Whatever attributes therefore you require as worthy of God, must be found in the Father, who is invisible and unapproachable, and placid, and (so to speak) the God of the philosophers; whereas those qualities which you censure as unworthy must be supposed to be in the Son, who has been seen, and heard, and encountered, the Witness and Servant of the Father, uniting in Himself man and God, God in mighty deeds, in weak ones man, in order that He may give to man as much as He takes from God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 27:17
verses.text: What in your esteem is the entire disgrace of my God, is in fact the sacrament of man's salvation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 27:18
verses.text: God held converse with man, that man might learn to act as God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 27:19
verses.text: God dealt on equal terms with man, that man might be able to deal on equal terms with God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 27:20
verses.text: God was found little, that man might become very great.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 27:21
verses.text: You who disdain such a God, I hardly know whether you ex fidebelieve that God was crucified.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 27:22
verses.text: How great, then, is your perversity in respect of the two characters of the Creator! You designate Him as Judge, and reprobate as cruelty that severity of the Judge which only acts in accord with the merits of cases.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 27:23
verses.text: You require God to be very good, and yet despise as meanness that gentleness of His which accorded with His kindness, (and) held lowly converse in proportion to the mediocrity of man's estate.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 27:24
verses.text: He pleases you not, whether great or little, neither as your judge nor as your friend! What if the same features should be discovered in your God? That He too is a judge, we have already shown in the proper section: that from being a judge He must needs be severe; and from being severe He must also be cruel, if indeed cruel.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 28:1
verses.text: The Tables Turned Upon Marcion, by Contrasts, in Favour of the True God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 28:2
verses.text: Now, touching the weaknesses and malignities, and the other (alleged), notes (of the Creator), I too shall advance antitheses in rivalry to Marcion's.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 28:3
verses.text: If my God knew not of any other superior to Himself, your god also was utterly unaware that there was any beneath himself.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 28:4
verses.text: It is just what Heraclitus "the obscure" said; whether it be up or down, it comes to the same thing.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 28:5
verses.text: If, indeed, he was not ignorant (of his position), it must have occurred to Him from the beginning.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 28:6
verses.text: Sin and death, and the author of sin too—the devil—and all the evil which my God permitted to be, this also, did your god permit; for he allowed Him to permit it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 28:7
verses.text: Our God changed His purposes; in like manner yours did also.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 28:8
verses.text: For he who cast his look so late in the human race, changed that purpose, which for so long a period had refused to cast that look.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 28:9
verses.text: Our God repented Him of the evil in a given case; so also did yours.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 28:10
verses.text: For by the fact that he at last had regard to the salvation of man, he showed such a repentance of his previous disregard as was due for a wrong deed.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 28:11
verses.text: But neglect of man's salvation will be accounted a wrong deed, simply because it has been remedied by his repentance in the conduct of your god.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 28:12
verses.text: Our God you say commanded a fraudulent act, but in a matter of gold and silver.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 28:13
verses.text: Now, inasmuch as man is more precious than gold and silver, in so far is your god more fraudulent still, because he robs man of his Lord and Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 28:14
verses.text: Eye for eye does our God require; but your god does even a greater injury, (in your ideas,) when he prevents an act of retaliation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 28:15
verses.text: For what man will not return a blow, without waiting to be struck a second time.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 28:16
verses.text: Our God (you say) knows not whom He ought to choose.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 28:17
verses.text: Nor does your god, for if he had foreknown the issue, he would not have chosen the traitor Judas.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 28:18
verses.text: If you allege that the Creator practised deception in any instance, there was a far greater mendacity in your Christ, whose very body was unreal.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 28:19
verses.text: Many were consumed by the severity of my God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 28:20
verses.text: Those also who were not saved by your god are verily disposed by him to ruin.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 28:21
verses.text: My God ordered a man to be slain.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 28:22
verses.text: Your god willed himself to be put to death; not less a homicide against himself than in respect of him by whom he meant to be slain.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 28:23
verses.text: I will moreover prove to Marcion that they were many who were slain by his god; for he made every one a homicide: in other words, he doomed him to perish, except when people failed in no duty towards Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 28:24
verses.text: But the straightforward virtue of truth is contented with few resources.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 28:25
verses.text: Many things will be necessary for falsehood.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 29:1
verses.text: Marcion's Own Antitheses, If Only the Title and Object of the Work Be Excepted, Afford Proofs of the Consistent Attributes of the True God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 29:2
verses.text: But I would have attacked Marcion's own Antitheses in closer and fuller combat, if a more elaborate demolition of them were required in maintaining for the Creator the character of a good God and a Judge, after the examples of both points, which we have shown to be so worthy of God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 29:3
verses.text: Since, however, these two attributes of goodness and justice do together make up the proper fulness of the Divine Being as omnipotent, I am able to content myself with having now compendiously refuted his Antitheses, which aim at drawing distinctions out of the qualities of the (Creator's) artifices, or of His laws, or of His great works; and thus sundering Christ from the Creator, as the most Good from the Judge, as One who is merciful from Him who is ruthless, and One who brings salvation from Him who causes ruin.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 29:4
verses.text: The truth is, they rather unite the two Beings whom they arrange in those diversities (of attribute), which yet are compatible in God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 29:5
verses.text: For only take away the title of Marcion's book, and the intention and purpose of the work itself, and you could get no better demonstration that the self-same God was both very good and a Judge, inasmuch as these two characters are only competently found in God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 29:6
verses.text: Indeed, the very effort which is made in the selected examples to oppose Christ to the Creator, conduces all the more to their union.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 29:7
verses.text: For so entirely one and the same was the nature of the Divine Beings, the good and the severe, as shown both by the same examples and in similar proofs, that It willed to display Its goodness to those on whom It had first inflicted Its severity.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 29:8
verses.text: The difference in time was no matter of surprise, when the same God was afterwards merciful in presence of evils which had been subdued, who had once been so austere whilst they were as yet unsubdued.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 29:9
verses.text: Thus, by help of the Antitheses, the dispensation of the Creator can be more readily shown to have been reformed by Christ, rather than destroyed; restored, rather than abolished; especially as you sever your own god from everything like acrimonious conduct, even from all rivalry whatsoever with the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 29:10
verses.text: Now, since this is the case, how comes it to pass that the Antitheses demonstrate Him to have been the Creator's rival in every disputed cause? Well, even here, too, I will allow that in these causes my God has been a jealous God, who has in His own right taken especial care that all things done by Him should be in their beginning of a robuster growth; and this in the way of a good, because rational emulation, which tends to maturity.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 29:11
verses.text: In this sense the world itself will acknowledge His "antitheses," from the contrariety of its own elements, although it has been regulated with the very highest reason.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 29:12
verses.text: Wherefore, most thoughtless Marcion, it was your duty to have shown that one (of the two Gods you teach) was a God of light, and the other a God of darkness; and then you would have found it an easier task to persuade us that one was a God of goodness, the other a God of severity.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book II 29:13
verses.text: How ever, the "antithesis" (or variety of administration) will rightly be His property, to whom it actually belongs in (the government of) the world.
